awd_abstract_narration:
In many areas of science and engineering differential equations are employed as
models of complex phenomena. The focus in this proposal is on the approximation
of solutions of infinite dimensional dynamical systems. In particular, the investigator
and his colleagues are interested in understanding the dynamics of the finite dimensional 
approximations and how they relate to the dynamics of the original dynamical system. 
The specific issues to be investigated are related to stability of solutions of spatially 
discrete reaction-diffusion equations, the dynamics of so-called anti-diffusion lattice 
differential equations, dynamics and computation of traveling waves for neutral mixed 
type functional differential equations and rigorous computation of periodic orbits 
for retarded delay equations, robust stability for time dependent linear Hamiltonian systems, 
numerical techniques for efficient computation of Lyapunov exponent like quantities based 
upon nonlinear flows, and approximation techniques for stability spectra of delay equations 
and partial differential equations. Techniques to investigate these systems combine 
numerical analysis and dynamical systems ideas to gain a better understanding of 
approximation dynamics. 

Often in complex systems the differential equations used in modeling are infinite 
dimensional, but necessarily these models are approximated by finite dimensional 
systems in order to perform numerical simulations. In order to understand the behavior of 
these models, the investigator and his colleagues are interested in similarities 
and differences in the behavior of the original infinite dimensional system and 
finite dimensional approximations, for example those obtained through discretization. 
Understanding the impact of discretization leads to greater confidence when 
making inferences from simulation results. In addition, stability analysis is useful 
in understanding the robustness of complex biological phenomena that occur in the 
environment and in identifying instabilities, for example, in models of weather prediction. 
Discrete models of both biological and physical processes are becoming more important as 
the need for detailed, microscopic models increases and should benefit from improved 
analysis and computational capabilities.

por.por_cntn:
This research project involves working with collaborators, graduate students, postdocs, and undergraduate students on approximation of infinite dimensional dynamics. The major effort has been in approximation of stability spectra for time varying infinite dimensional dynamical systems and on the dynamics of waves in lattice (typically discrete in space/continuous in time) differential equations used in the modeling of physical and biological systems.  One of the major goals of this project was to develop error analysis for computation of stability spectra (Lyapunov exponents and Sacker-Sell spectrum) for infinite dimensional dynamical systems. These are used to determine the convergence to or divergence from of nearby time dependent solutions of a time dependent solution. This error analysis has been sucessfully applied to two important classes of infinite dimensional dynamical systems: parabolic partial differential equations used to model heat flow and reaction-diffusion systems and delay differential equations used in the modeling of population dynamics and predator-prey dynamics. Another major goal was analyze wave like or traveling wave solutions of lattice differential equations some of which are analogous to spatial discretizations of partial differential equations while some do not have a continuum limit that is a partial differential equation but are derived as models in their own right. Graduate students, postdocs, and undergraduate students are involved in working together on this research project and they have given talks and attended workshops, and have also received training in high performance computing techniques. Results have been disseminated through journal publications, lectures in seminars and at conferences, and through organization of conferences, workshops, and  special sections at conferences.

 



Last Modified: 12/29/2015
Modified by: Erik S Van Vleck

This error analysis has been sucessfully applied to two important classes of infinite dimensional dynamical systems: parabolic partial differential equations used to model heat flow and reaction-diffusion systems and delay differential equations used in the modeling of population dynamics and predator-prey dynamics.
